text: this is the halat Detention Center in
the middle of the Negev desert the
people here say they came to Israel to
seek refuge from conflict or persecution
but the Israeli government has granted
asylum to fewer than 1%
it says the migrants have become a
threat to the security and identity of
the Jewish state the government calls
this an open stay Center but it's run by
the Prison Service and conditions are
strict at nighttime is the curfew so
residents have to report back by 10:00
p.m. they're not allowed to work either
and in such an isolated area there are
very few things to do during the day if
someone is living here in Horeb
is mean that you have no fishing if
somebody come to Hallowed and get crazy
that his mind is not recover forever
this man is already dead the residents
can be held here for 12 months after
that the choice is dark they can return
home or they can agree to go and live in
a third country in Africa and if they
refuse either of these options they
could be sent to prison indefinitely the
BBC has spoken to people who say they
were sent to Rwanda and Uganda and that
Israel's promises that they will receive
basic protections there are not being
fulfilled test-fire who's now in Kenya
says he was sent to Rwanda two days
after he arrived he told us he was
forced to pay a man called John to
smuggle him into Uganda we'll cross the
border that what I understand we are
smuggling illegal border-crossing
it's not been what they are promising
it's totally have no any safe have no
protection at all the wonders president
Paul Kagame has only said that his
government has been in talks with Israel
over hosting its migrants and has never
confirmed a deal Uganda has denied
outright that such a deal exists but has
told the BBC it's now investigating how
migrants who claim to be sent from
Israel are entering the country in
Kampala this man who's from Darfur told
us that he was sent from Israel to
Uganda with
and others and his papers were taken
from him at the airport when he arrived
none of the things that I was being
promised was given to me none of things
they just want to take people and dump
them anywhere else he told us that after
nine months he did manage to get refugee
status in Uganda the lack of
transparency in the so called voluntary
departure process to third countries
raises many questions questions that
have led legal experts to argue that
Israel is in breach of its obligations
under the UN Refugee Convention the lack
of proper moral monitoring
I think cannot cannot really secure in
the necessary certainty that those
people would not end up you know either
without status or in prison or worst of
all being returned to places where they
would face danger the Israeli government
told me that it has absolutely no doubt
that it's acting within the framework of
international law I am confident that we
act here in Israel according to the
highest standards they now whatever
happens within the poses is something
that we deal with in our bilateral
relations with other countries that view
is do to be challenged next month in a
case at the Supreme Court it can only
give hope to those who search continues
for a normal life and a place of safety
Kathy Hawken
BBC News
